column1: Table 3:   Comparison between visceral and somatic pain

column2:
Stretching and distension, 
producing poorly localised pain.
column3:
Mechanical, thermal, chemical and 
electrical stimuli, producing well 
localised pain.

column2:
Widespread stimulation produces 
significantly magnified pain.
column3:
Widespread stimulation produces a 
modest increase in pain.

column2:
Autonomic features (e.g., nausea 
and sweating) frequently present.

Pain perceived at a site distant to 
the cause of the pain is common.
column3:
Pain is relatively well localised and 
well recognised.

column2:
Referred cutaneous and muscle 
hyperalgesia is common, as is 
involvement of other visceral 
organs.

Low density, unmyelinated C fibres 
and thinly myelinated Aâˆ‚ fibres.
column3:
Dense innervation with a wide 
range of nerve fibres.

column2:
Intensity coding. As stimulation 
increases, afferent firing increases 
with an increase in sensation and 
ultimately pain.
column3:
Two fibre coding. Separate fibres 
for pain and normal sensation.

column2:
50-90% of visceral afferents 
are silent until the time they are 
switched on.
column3:
These fibres are very important in 
the central sensitisation process. 
Silent afferents present, but form a 
lower percentage.

column2:
Play an important part in the 
hyperalgesia, viscero-visceral, 
viscero-muscular and musculo-
visceral hyperalgesia.
column3:
Sensations not normally perceived 
become perceived and non-
noxious sensations become 
painful. Responsible for the 
allodynia and hyperalgesia of 
chronic somatic pain.

column2:
Central mechanisms associated 
with visceral pain may be 
responsible for organ dysfunction.
column3:
Somatic pain associated with 
somatic dysfunction, e.g., muscle 
spasm.

column2:
As well as classical pathways, 
there is evidence for a separate 
dorsal horn pathway and central 
representation.
